newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Internet set for continued growth, Gates says.
newsitem.headline: Internet set for continued growth, Gates says.

text.p: Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates said on Monday the Internet global computer network was so big and attracting so much investment it would keep growing and overcome its current drawbacks.
Gates told delegates at a telecommunications conference the Internet had several temporary limitations, including lack of security and some capacity problems.

"These limitations do exist but there are so many companies, including my own, that are hard at work to eliminate these limitations, that I have no doubt the Internet would continue to charge ahead," Gates said via teleconference.
"The level of investment, particularly in the U.S., but also around the world, is quite amazing," he said.
"There is no doubt the critical mass has been achieved."
Gates said the Internet would transform global communications in ways currently not thought of.
"It is the most important thing to happen for the communications world since the development of the first personal computer, over 16 years ago," he said.
Gates said the fastest area of growth was in Asia.
"In Asia only two percent of homes have PCs, however, over 12 million PCs were sold in Asia over the last year, and it is the fastest growing market for computers."
"It is also the fastest growing market for the Internet with over three million users now connected up, and every two years we expect that to more than double," Gates said.
It said that as the Internet grew the applications available for its use would multiply with video and audio communications becoming commonplace, first among businesses and eventually in the home.
"Someday kids will spend more time on a PC connected to the Internet than in front of the TV," he said. "It will be a much richer experience."
